title: The Bug We've All Written
content:
The Bug We've All Written

‚ùå The Naive Approach

def average_angle(angle1, angle2):
    return (angle1 + angle2) / 2  # Seems reasonable...

# Example: Average heading between two compass readings
heading1 = 350  # degrees
heading2 = 10   # degrees

average = average_angle(heading1, heading2)
print(f"Average: {average}¬∞")  # 180¬∞ - COMPLETELY WRONG!

What Went Wrong?

  • 350¬∞ and 10¬∞ are 20¬∞ apart on the circle
  • But linear math sees them as 340¬∞ apart
  • The average points in the opposite direction!

The Code Behind It

function circularAverage(a1, a2) {
    // Convert to radians
    const theta1 = a1 * Math.PI / 180;
    const theta2 = a2 * Math.PI / 180;
    
    // Embed on unit circle
    const v1 = [Math.cos(theta1), Math.sin(theta1)];
    const v2 = [Math.cos(theta2), Math.sin(theta2)];
    
    // Average vectors
    const avgVec = [(v1[0] + v2[0])/2, (v1[1] + v2[1])/2];
    
    // Convert back to angle
    const avgTheta = Math.atan2(avgVec[1], avgVec[0]);
    return (avgTheta * 180 / Math.PI + 360) % 360;
}

title: Real Example: Robot/Drone Heading Control
content:
Real Example: Robot/Drone Heading Control

ü§ñ The Scenario

PID controller needs to turn robot from 350¬∞ to 10¬∞

‚ùå Naive PID Error

error = target - current
error = 10 - 350 = -340¬∞
# Robot spins almost full circle
# the wrong way!

‚úÖ Embedded Solution

def heading_error(current, target):
    c_vec = [cos(current), sin(current)]
    t_vec = [cos(target), sin(target)]
    return atan2(cross(c_vec, t_vec), 
                 dot(c_vec, t_vec))
# Returns: +20¬∞ (shortest path!)

Complete PID Controller Fix

class HeadingController:
    def __init__(self, kp=1.0, ki=0.1, kd=0.05):
        self.kp, self.ki, self.kd = kp, ki, kd
        self.integral = 0
        self.last_error = 0
        
    def compute_control(self, current_heading, target_heading, dt):
        # Embed both headings as vectors
        current_vec = np.array([np.cos(current_heading), np.sin(current_heading)])
        target_vec = np.array([np.cos(target_heading), np.sin(target_heading)])
        
        # Compute signed angle error (always shortest path)
        error = np.arctan2(
            current_vec[0] * target_vec[1] - current_vec[1] * target_vec[0],
            current_vec[0] * target_vec[0] + current_vec[1] * target_vec[1]
        )
        
        # Standard PID computation (now with correct error!)
        self.integral += error * dt
        derivative = (error - self.last_error) / dt
        
        control = self.kp * error + self.ki * self.integral + self.kd * derivative
        self.last_error = error
        
        return control  # Angular velocity command

üí∞ Real Impact: Shipping routes crossing the Pacific get drawn spanning ~359¬∞ longitude instead of the short ~20 nautical mile path due to antimeridian wraparound bugs in mapping SDKs

It's not just angles, time, and colors that wrap around. Here are the sneaky cyclic variables that cause bugs when you least expect them:

üí° The Universal Solution

üéØ When to Suspect a Hidden Ring

üö© Red Flags in Your Data

title: üåç GIS Demo: Longitude Wraparound at the International Date Line
content:
üåç GIS Demo: Longitude Wraparound at the International Date Line

Real-World Problem: Computing Geographic Means

When averaging GPS coordinates near ¬±180¬∞ longitude (International Date Line), linear arithmetic fails spectacularly. A farm field split by the date line appears to span the entire globe!

Circular mean: ‚Ä¶

üéØ Try This: Drag the markers across the International Date Line!

Red marker = Wrong linear mean | Green marker = Correct circular mean

Watch how the linear mean jumps to the middle of the Atlantic while the circular mean stays put! This is the classic longitude wraparound bug.

Spherical Coordinate Embedding

# For full lat/long geometry operations
def latlon_to_cartesian(lat, lon):
    """Embed (lat,lon) in R¬≥ for linear operations"""
    lat_rad = np.radians(lat)
    lon_rad = np.radians(lon)
    return np.array([
        np.cos(lat_rad) * np.cos(lon_rad),  # x
        np.cos(lat_rad) * np.sin(lon_rad),  # y  
        np.sin(lat_rad)                     # z
    ])

# Geographic centroid (works across antimeridian!)
def geographic_centroid(lat_lon_pairs):
    cartesian_points = [latlon_to_cartesian(lat, lon) 
                       for lat, lon in lat_lon_pairs]
    mean_cartesian = np.mean(cartesian_points, axis=0)
    mean_cartesian /= np.linalg.norm(mean_cartesian)  # Back to unit sphere
    
    # Convert back to lat/lon
    lat = np.degrees(np.arcsin(mean_cartesian[2]))
    lon = np.degrees(np.arctan2(mean_cartesian[1], mean_cartesian[0]))
    return lat, lon

  • Spatial Statistics: Computing true centroids for service areas
  • Route Optimization: Distance calculations that work globally
  • Geofencing: Boundary checks that don't break at meridians
  • Data Quality: Detecting GPS outliers using proper spherical distance

title: When Zero Isn't Special: Arbitrary Wrap Points
content:
When Zero Isn't Special: Arbitrary Wrap Points

üéØ Real Hardware Doesn't Care About Zero

Many circular quantities in the wild wrap at arbitrary values, not nice round numbers. The math still works‚Äîyou just need to normalize first!

üìä Common Non-Zero Wrap Domains

üß≠ Compass: [-180¬∞, +180¬∞)

Wraps at ¬±180¬∞, not 0¬∞/360¬∞

bearing ‚àà [-180, 180)

üîß Rotary Encoder: [1000, 5096)

12-bit encoder with arbitrary offset

counts ‚àà [1000, 5096)

üì° Phase: [-œÄ, +œÄ)

Centered around zero, not starting at it

phase ‚àà [-œÄ, œÄ)

üóìÔ∏è Fiscal Year: [Apr, Mar]

Wraps at March/April boundary

month ‚àà [4, 3] (mod 12)

üå°Ô∏è ADC Values: [512, 3584)

Sensor with DC offset and limited range

adc ‚àà [512, 3584)

‚ú® The Universal Transform

For any circular quantity:

value ‚àà [min, max)

‚Üì

1. Normalize to [0, 1):

t = (value - min) / (max - min)

‚Üì

2. Embed on unit circle:

v = (cos(2œÄt), sin(2œÄt))

‚Üì

3. Do your math in ‚Ñù¬≤

‚Üì

4. Project back if needed:

result = min + (max-min) √ó atan2(v.y, v.x)/(2œÄ)

üíª Code Example: Averaging Compass Bearings

# PROBLEM: Compass uses [-180¬∞, +180¬∞) not [0¬∞, 360¬∞)
bearings = [170, 175, -175, -170]  # All pointing roughly south

# WRONG: Simple average
naive_mean = np.mean(bearings)  # = 0¬∞ (North!) ü§¶

# RIGHT: Normalize ‚Üí Embed ‚Üí Average ‚Üí Denormalize
def circular_mean(values, min_val, max_val):
    # Step 1: Normalize to [0, 1)
    period = max_val - min_val
    normalized = [(v - min_val) / period for v in values]
    
    # Step 2: Embed on circle
    vectors = [(np.cos(2*np.pi*t), np.sin(2*np.pi*t)) for t in normalized]
    
    # Step 3: Average in vector space
    mean_vector = np.mean(vectors, axis=0)
    
    # Step 4: Project back to original domain
    angle = np.atan2(mean_vector[1], mean_vector[0])
    result = min_val + (angle / (2*np.pi)) * period
    if result < min_val:
        result += period
    return result

correct_mean = circular_mean(bearings, -180, 180)  # ‚âà 175¬∞ South! ‚úÖ

üîß Practical Examples

üéÆ Game Development

# Joystick angle ‚àà [-œÄ, œÄ]
js_angle = atan2(js.y, js.x)
# Don't compare directly!
# Normalize first

ü§ñ Robotics

# Encoder wraps at 8192
# but starts at 1000
actual_pos = 1000 + 
  (raw - 1000) % 7192

üìä Time Series

# Fiscal quarters Q2-Q1
# April = month 0

  (cal_month - 4) % 12

üéØ Key Insight

The "zero point" is arbitrary! What matters is the topology‚Äîthat values wrap around.

Always normalize to [0, 1) or [0, 2œÄ) before embedding. Your vector math doesn't care where the original wrap point was.

title: The General Pattern
content:
The General Pattern

Any Circular Quantity Can Be Embedded!

Wraparound Quantity Traditional Problems Embedding Solution Benefits
Angle
Œ∏ ‚àà [0, 2œÄ)		 Gimbal lock, discontinuities (cos Œ∏, sin Œ∏) ‚àà ‚Ñù¬≤ Smooth interpolation
Time of Day
t ‚àà [0, 24)		 Midnight wraparound (cos 2œÄt/24, sin 2œÄt/24) No special cases
Day of Week
d ‚àà {0..6}		 Weekend averaging e^(2œÄid/7) or 7D one-hot Correct statistics
Phase
œÜ ‚àà [-œÄ, œÄ)		 Phase unwrapping e^(iœÜ) ‚àà ‚ÑÇ Natural operations
Encoder Position
n ‚àà [0, 4096)		 Rollover detection (cos 2œÄn/4096, sin 2œÄn/4096) Continuous tracking

One Class to Rule Them All

class CircularQuantity:
    """Universal handler for any quantity that wraps around"""
    
    def __init__(self, value, period):
        self.period = period
        self.value = value % period  # Normalize to [0, period)
        
        # THE KEY: Embed on unit circle
        theta = 2 * np.pi * self.value / period
        self.vec = np.array([np.cos(theta), np.sin(theta)])
    
    def shortest_distance_to(self, other):
        """Always returns shortest signed distance"""
        angle = np.arctan2(
            self.vec[0] * other.vec[1] - self.vec[1] * other.vec[0],
            self.vec[0] * other.vec[0] + self.vec[1] * other.vec[1]
        )
        return angle * self.period / (2 * np.pi)
    
    def average_with(self, others):
        """Proper circular mean"""
        all_vecs = [self.vec] + [o.vec for o in others]
        mean_vec = np.mean(all_vecs, axis=0)
        mean_vec /= np.linalg.norm(mean_vec)  # Renormalize
        
        angle = np.arctan2(mean_vec[1], mean_vec[0])
        mean_value = angle * self.period / (2 * np.pi)
        return CircularQuantity(mean_value, self.period)
    
    def interpolate_to(self, other, t):
        """Smooth interpolation along shortest path"""
        # SLERP for perfect circular interpolation
        dot = np.dot(self.vec, other.vec)
        omega = np.arccos(np.clip(dot, -1, 1))
        
        if abs(omega) < 1e-10:  # Vectors are identical
            return self
        
        vec_t = (np.sin((1-t)*omega)/np.sin(omega) * self.vec +
                 np.sin(t*omega)/np.sin(omega) * other.vec)
        
        angle = np.arctan2(vec_t[1], vec_t[0])
        value = angle * self.period / (2 * np.pi)
        return CircularQuantity(value, self.period)

üìê Angles

a1 = CircularQuantity(350, 360)
a2 = CircularQuantity(10, 360)
dist = a1.shortest_distance_to(a2)
# Result: 20¬∞

‚è∞ Time

t1 = CircularQuantity(23.5, 24)
t2 = CircularQuantity(0.5, 24)
avg = t1.average_with([t2])
# Result: 0.0 (midnight)

üìÖ Weekdays

        CircularQuantity(0, 7),  # Sun
        CircularQuantity(1, 7)]  # Mon
avg = days[0].average_with(days[1:])
# Result: 0 (Sunday)

e2 = CircularQuantity(10, 4096)

# Result: 20 counts

title: The Mathematical Insight
content:
The Mathematical Insight

Why Does This Work?

A circle (S¬π) is topologically different from a line segment. Linear math breaks at the wraparound point.

üåê The Circle Problem

  • Circles have no "beginning" or "end"
  • 359¬∞ and 1¬∞ are neighbors
  • But arithmetic says 359 - 1 = 358 ü§¶
  • ‚Üí Solution: Use 2D vectors instead!

üîÑ The Wrapping Function

Angles wrap around: 370¬∞ = 10¬∞, 730¬∞ = 10¬∞, etc. The infinite line wraps onto the finite circle.

üîë The Universal Pattern

Problem Space

Non-linear manifold

(circle, sphere, torus)

Embedding

Lift to linear space

(‚Ñù¬≤, ‚Ñù¬≥, ‚ÑÇ)

Computation

Do linear algebra

(add, average, interpolate)

Projection

Map back to manifold

(atan2, normalize)

üéØ Where Else This Appears

  • Quaternions: 3D rotations in 4D space
  • Complex Numbers: 2D rotations in ‚ÑÇ
  • Fourier Transform: Signals on unit circle
  • Neural Networks: Learned embeddings

üí≠ Mathematical Insight

"The introduction of numbers as coordinates is an act of violence."
‚Äî Hermann Weyl

But sometimes, the right coordinates make the violence worthwhile!

content:
Circular Statistics: The Hidden Superpower

ü§Ø What Statistics Class Never Taught You

Standard statistics breaks horribly on circular data. But vector embedding makes circular statistics trivially easy‚Äîand incredibly powerful!

üìä The Problem with Regular Stats

‚ú® Vector Statistics = Magic

title: Discrete Calculus on Circles: Data-Driven Operations
content:
Discrete Calculus on Circles: Data-Driven Operations

üìä Real-World Data = Discrete Samples

In practice, we don't have continuous functions‚Äîwe have time series data of circular quantities. How do we compute derivatives and integrals when our data wraps around?

üìà Discrete Derivatives (Angular Velocity)

# WRONG: Naive difference breaks at wraparound
angles = [358¬∞, 359¬∞, 1¬∞, 2¬∞]  # Smooth rotation
naive_diff = [1¬∞, 2¬∞, -357¬∞]  # HUGE SPIKE! üí•

# RIGHT: Vector space derivative
vectors = [(cos(Œ∏), sin(Œ∏)) for Œ∏ in angles]
dvdt = [(v[i+1] - v[i])/dt for i in range(len(v)-1)]

# Angular velocity from vector derivative
œâ = cross_product(v[i], dvdt[i]) / |v[i]|¬≤
# Result: [1¬∞/s, 1¬∞/s, 1¬∞/s] ‚úÖ

üìâ Discrete Integrals (Accumulated Rotation)

# WRONG: Sum angles directly
angular_velocities = [90¬∞/s, 90¬∞/s, 90¬∞/s, 90¬∞/s]
naive_sum = sum(angular_velocities) * dt  # 360¬∞???

# RIGHT: Accumulate in vector space
v_accumulated = [1, 0]  # Start at 0¬∞
for œâ in angular_velocities:
    # Rotate vector by angular increment
    dŒ∏ = œâ * dt
    rotation = [[cos(dŒ∏), -sin(dŒ∏)],
                [sin(dŒ∏), cos(dŒ∏)]]
    v_accumulated = rotation @ v_accumulated

final_angle = atan2(v_accumulated)  # Correct!

üîß Practical Applications in Data Science

üåä Wind Speed Analysis

# Wind direction time series (sampled every hour)
wind_dirs = [350¬∞, 355¬∞, 0¬∞, 5¬∞, 10¬∞]  # North-ish
wind_speeds = [10, 12, 15, 14, 11]  # mph

# Compute wind vector components
u = [-speed * sin(dir) for speed, dir in zip(wind_speeds, wind_dirs)]
v = [-speed * cos(dir) for speed, dir in zip(wind_speeds, wind_dirs)]

# Now can compute proper derivatives!
du_dt = np.gradient(u)  # Wind acceleration (east)
dv_dt = np.gradient(v)  # Wind acceleration (north)

ü§ñ Robot Heading Tracking

# IMU gives heading samples at 100Hz
headings = sensor.get_heading_buffer()  # [Œ∏‚ÇÅ, Œ∏‚ÇÇ, ..., Œ∏‚Çô]
dt = 0.01  # 10ms between samples

# Convert to unit vectors
vectors = [(cos(h), sin(h)) for h in headings]

# Compute angular velocity using discrete derivative
angular_vel = []
for i in range(len(vectors)-1):
    # Cross product gives rotation rate
    œâ = (vectors[i][0]*vectors[i+1][1] - 
         vectors[i][1]*vectors[i+1][0]) / dt
    angular_vel.append(œâ)

# Smooth using windowed average (no wraparound issues!)
smoothed_œâ = moving_average(angular_vel, window=10)

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls with Discrete Circular Data

‚ùå Phase Unwrapping

unwrap([350¬∞, 10¬∞]) ‚Üí [350¬∞, 370¬∞]

Creates artificial trends! Use vectors instead.

‚ùå Modulo Arithmetic

(Œ∏‚ÇÇ - Œ∏‚ÇÅ) % 360

Loses direction info. Vector difference preserves it.

‚ùå Averaging Raw Angles

mean([0¬∞, 90¬∞, 180¬∞, 270¬∞]) ‚Üí 135¬∞

Should be undefined! Vector mean ‚Üí 0.

üéØ The Key Pattern for Discrete Operations

Discrete Samples ‚Üí Vector Time Series ‚Üí Standard Numpy Operations ‚Üí Interpret Results

Œ∏[t] ‚Üí [cos(Œ∏[t]), sin(Œ∏[t])] ‚Üí np.gradient(), np.cumsum() ‚Üí atan2() if needed

Bottom Line: NumPy/Pandas operations "just work" on vector representations‚Äîno special circular functions needed!

title: Key Takeaways
content:
Key Takeaways

üéØ The Golden Rule

When you see a quantity that wraps around,

ask: "Can I embed this on a circle?"

Your Debugging Checklist

‚úì

Spot the Wraparound

Does your value jump discontinuously? (359¬∞ ‚Üí 0¬∞, 11:59 PM ‚Üí 12:00 AM)

‚úì

Identify the Period

What's the cycle length? (360¬∞ for angles, 24 hours for time, 7 for weekdays)

‚úì

Choose Your Embedding

Usually: (cos(2œÄxT), sin(2œÄxT)) where T is the period

‚úì

Work in Vector Space

Do all math on the vectors, not the raw values

‚úì

Project Back When Needed

Use atan2(y, x) to recover the original quantity
